responses.content: We have architected Azure for a distributed computing fabric, emphasizing hybrid and multi-cloud infrastructures. This approach supports low latency access for applications like factory floors, hospitals, and gaming, ensuring our position in a multi-cloud, multi-edge world remains strong.

Overall, we see a strong demand signal. Post-pandemic economic constraints drive businesses to adopt digital technology to enhance productivity and reduce costs. Products like PowerApps and our cloud services across security, infrastructure, business applications, and Teams are experiencing robust demand.

In gaming, we are doubling down on our consumer category with initiatives like Xbox Game Pass Ultimate and xCloud. These services expand our reach beyond traditional consoles and PCs, enhancing the gaming experience through cloud-based services.

The metaverse opportunity spans our entire tech stack, from Azure IoT and digital twins to Dynamics 365 Connected Spaces and immersive Teams experiences. We are investing across platform infrastructure and application layers to support the development of the metaverse, leveraging our strengths in AI, cloud, and gaming.

Our focus remains on allocating resources to high-growth, differentiated areas, driving operating leverage and margin improvements. Operating expenses are expected to grow in line with headcount growth and strategic investments.

Azure's seasonality has decreased as consumption grows consistently, particularly in high-growth and premium SKUs. Operating expenses are expected to align with headcount growth, and gross margins will benefit from a shift towards higher-margin services.

Despite supply chain challenges, Windows OEM numbers exceeded guidance due to strong demand in the commercial segment. Higher revenue per license in the commercial market contributed to robust performance in Q1 and Q2.

Large enterprise commitments are driven by the comprehensive scope of Microsoft Cloud offerings, including Dynamics, Power Platform, Microsoft 365, and Azure. These commitments reflect strong renewals, recapture rates, and add-ons across our product suite.
Our cash flow is expected to grow in line with operating income, supported by strong sales, improving margins in the cloud, and effective business execution.

Inflationary pressures are being offset by productivity gains from digital transformation. Our investments in high-growth areas and efficient operational controls ensure that we maintain strong gross margins and operational efficiency.

questions: I wanted to ask you guys a high-level question about the overall demand environment and whether we’ve seen any changes, given sort of the disruptions we’ve seen from Omicron and a lot of what’s going on in the environment. There’s been a narrative among software investors and a lot of time the asset prices seem the narrative. I wanted to check in with you guys on how you feel about the overall demand environment, particularly around digital transformation and how durable is that going to be into calendar year ‘22? Do you still see a lot of wood to chop, if you will, a lot of activity taking place in that direction. Thank you.

Amy, commercial bookings up 14% is impressive, but it’s slowed down from last quarter’s 25 against a more difficult comp. I think you’d mentioned some color around Azure, and the size and duration. Can you just, maybe anything else you would call out there? I realize it’s coming off the tough comps.

Amy, heading into this Q1 release, I’d say there was a higher than normal level of worry from investors about your Windows PC segments, in light of all of the unit shipment and supply chain issues. And yet, you put up a Windows OEM number that blew away your guidance. And your guidance for the Windows OEM business in December was also, I think, way above what people are modeling. I guess, in essence, how did you dodge that bullet? Amy, maybe you could unpack that OEM performance for us and your view into the second half of the fiscal year. Thank you.

With inflation, at least in the U.S. increasing and likely to further accelerate due to government spending, Amy, how do you think this increasing inflation will impact your customers and your business? And Satya, in your remarks, you discussed how digital is deflationary in an inflationary world. Can you give more color on how the shift to cloud and digital offset inflationary pressure beyond purely pricing? Thank you.

Given all the commentary on the metaverse, what are the key components of the metaverse or the multiple metaverses that you’re seeing? What does Microsoft have today that they’re positioned to be able to deliver to meet those requirements and what do you believe you might be lacking in the partner ecosystem to meet those requirements? Amy, with the hype cycle underway and increased industry interest in the metaverse, are you changing your investments to meet the potential opportunity?

Maybe I wanted to ask a little bit philosophically, Satya. The pandemic clearly accelerated everyone’s timeline to migrate to the cloud, even if there wasn’t necessarily a big pull forward there. As we think about a post-Omicron world where there is some level of office re-openings and visibility into that, how should we think about the potential to see maybe another wave or another acceleration of those cloud migrations with that ability to have in office and have hybrid work? Maybe walk us through that. Thank you.

With Office 365 commercial showing another strong quarter in terms of revenue and seat growth, particularly in SMB and frontline workers, and an increase in revenue per user, can you walk us through the growth algorithm here? How might this change going forward versus what you have seen?

Recently, several of your tier one SIs have talked about having trouble hiring fast enough to keep up with demand. And clearly, your results sort of speak to that. But as we look going forward, have you seen any early indications that customers are potentially having to slow down the pace at which they move to your commercial cloud? Thanks.
